subject_id.name: Subject_ID
subject_id.note: For cases in which an individual conducted multiple attacks or plots, these questions refer primarily to the plot that resulted in the individual's exposure, which is usually the final plot.
subject_id.description: Unique 4-digit numerical identifier for each individual in the dataset.
subject_id.rest_text: Variable  Plot and Consequences The variables in this section capture details pertaining to the first publically known plot or extremist activity associated with the individual. This includes information about important dates, locations, targets, preparations, and consequences related to the activity. Plot

loc_plot_state/loc_plot_city.name: Loc_Plot_State/Loc_Plot_City
loc_plot_state/loc_plot_city.description: Enter the U.S. state and city or foreign country where the first publically known extremist plot/activity was centered. This could include where the person was arrested, where he/she did most of his/her training, or where the individual intended to attack. In essence, it records the location most commonly associated in the media with the individual plot/activity. If unknown, list -99.
loc_plot_state/loc_plot_city.rest_text: Keshif Label(s): Location of Extremist Activities (City/State) Variable

date_exposure.name: Date_Exposure
date_exposure.description: Enter the date (using the format MM/DD/YYYY) at which the individual’s activity/plot first came to public attention. This is usually time of incident or arrest, or earliest mention of individual in sources, so long as these are related to the plot/radicalization of the individual. If unknown, list -99. If only month and year are known, then assume first day of the month.
date_exposure.rest_text: Keshif Label(s): Year of Exposure Variable

plot_target.name: Plot_Target
plot_target.description: If the individual's first publically known extremist activity included a violent plot, enter the target type or intended target type of the plot. Select up to three target types. If unknown, list -99. If there is no violent plot or no specific plot target, list -88.

attack_preparation.name: Attack_Preparation
attack_preparation.description: If the individual's first publically known extremist activity involved a violent plot, what type of preparation did the individual engage in before being publicly exposed as an extremist?

codes.-88: Not Applicable (for cases where the individual was not associated with any attack or violent plot)
codes.2: Extensive planning (including obtaining significant amounts of information on the target—including both research and casing or active observation—and familiarity with the planned tactics, such as through research, training and “dry runs” of the operation)
codes.1: Moderate planning (minimal preparation, such as obtaining information on the target and rudimentary familiarity with planned tactics, but not more extensive preparation like casing the target or performing “dry runs” of the operation).

op_security.name: Op_Security
op_security.description: If the individual's first publically known extremist activity involved a violent plot, did the individual attempt to hide or conceal preparation for the plot?
op_security.rest_text: Keshif Label(s): Hide or Conceal Plot Variable

codes.-88: Not Applicable (for cases where the individual was not associated with any attack or violent plot)
codes.2: Yes (avoided discussion with friends and associates and used code words when discussing the plot, procured supplies through intermediaries or in areas outside place of habitation or target area, etc.)
codes.1: The individual was neither covert nor overt (did not discuss the plot openly or overtly procure supplies, but also did not attempt to hide activities).
codes.0: No, was openly vocal about the plot (discussed it with friends and associates, procured suspicious supplies—like explosives or weapons—without being discrete, etc.)

changing_target.name: Changing_Target
changing_target.description: If the individual's first publically known extremist activity involved a violent plot, did the target of the plot change as the plot developed?

codes.-88: Not Applicable (for cases where the individual was not associated with any attack or violent plot)

anticipated_fatalities_target.name: Anticipated_Fatalities_Target
anticipated_fatalities_target.description: If the individual was involved in a violent plot, how many victims did the subject anticipate would be killed?

codes.-88: Not Applicable (for cases where the individual was not associated with any attack or violent plot)

internet_use_plot.name: Internet_Use_Plot
internet_use_plot.note: This does not include radicalizing through the internet, which is addressed in another question.
internet_use_plot.description: If the individual's extremist activity involved a violent plot, did the individual use the internet for communications or logistics while preparing for and undertaking the plot? This includes using the internet to communicate with group members or other extremists, threatening targets, researching the target and tactics, and ordering supplies.

codes.-88: Not Applicable (for cases where the individual was not associated with any violent plot, or for when the plot occurred before 1995).

extent_plot.name: Extent_Plot
extent_plot.description: If the individual's extremist activity involved a violent plot, to what extent did the plot progress? I.e., how far did the planning and execution proceed?
extent_plot.rest_text: Keshif Label(s): Plot Progress Extent Variable   Consequences

codes.4: Attempted and failed execution of plot
codes.3: Acquisition and possession of materials for plot
codes.2: Attempted acquisition of materials for plot
codes.1: Nebulous plot (general ideas only, threats made to targets in the absence of an planning or preparation)

violent.name: Violent
violent.description: Did the individual actively participate in ideologically motivated operations/actions that resulted in causalities/injuries or clearly intended to result in causalities/injuries (but failed), or were they charged with conspiracy to kill or injure but were interdicted in the plotting phase? Examples of violent operations/plots include murder, assault, armed robbery, kidnapping, bombing, and arson (but not if they purposely avoid human causalities). Examples of nonviolent ideologically motivated operations/actions include property destruction/vandalism, illegal protest, armed standoffs that were defused without injury, receiving “terrorist” training but not acting on it, inciting others to violence but no direct action themselves, threatening violent actions without operational progress toward a plot, possession of illegal weapons without operational plans for violence, and “paper terrorism” tactics (e.g. filing false liens, tax fraud, etc.).

criminal_severity.name: Criminal_Severity
criminal_severity.description: Enter the maximum extent of the individual’s radical criminal activity by the time of public exposure.

codes.10: Violence against person(s)/armed robbery/assault with deadly weapon
codes.5: Training/seeking training/material support to a violent extremist organization/unlawful possession
codes.4: Recruiting others for violent group/incitement (indirect actions)
codes.1: Conspiracy after the fact (e.g., making false statements)

criminal_charges.name: Criminal_Charges
criminal_charges.description: If the individual was charged/arrested/indicted for an ideologically motivated crime as a result of their public exposure, indicate the type of crime the individual was charged/arrested/indicted for.

codes.-88: Not Applicable (the individual was never arrested, charged, or indicted for an ideologically motivated crime)

indict_arrest.name: Indict_Arrest
indict_arrest.description: If the individual was arrested or indicted for an ideologically motivated crime as a result of their public exposure, indicate whether the individual was indicted for the crime, arrested, or both.
indict_arrest.rest_text: Keshif Label(s): Indicted or Arrested Variable   -88= Not Applicable

codes.4: Indicted and arrested (unless otherwise stated, you can assume a person who was indicted was also arrested)
codes.3: Indicted only (in rare circumstances a person can be indicted before being arrested)

current_status.name: Current_Status
current_status.description: Current status of individual according to latest sources at the time of coding.

codes.9: Killed by adversary (e.g., other extremist groups)
codes.8: Killed by law enforcement or military
codes.1: At large (not being pursued by the government)

group_membership.name: Group_Membership
group_membership.note: Refer to the Inclusion Criteria section for instructions on how to interpret group membership.
group_membership.description: Was the individual in a group? If the individual is both a member of a formal extremist organization and an above-ground political movement or activist group, enter 3 for member of formal extremist organization. If individual is member of both an informal group of fellow extremists and a formal extremist organization, enter 3 for member of formal extremist organization. If the individual is a member of both an informal group of extremists and an above-ground political movement/activist group, enter 2 for informal group of extremists.

codes.3: Member of a formal extremist organization or an extremist movement (e.g., Weather Underground, Animal Liberation Front, al-Qaeda)
codes.2: Member of an informal group of fellow extremists (e.g., a ‘homegrown’ cell or informal militia)
codes.1: Member of an above-ground political movement or activist group (e.g., Operation Rescue, Earth First!)
codes.0: Not a member of a group

terrorist_group_name.name: Terrorist_Group_Name
terrorist_group_name.description: Name of existing Designated Terrorist Organization or extremist group with which individual is affiliated. Include those organizations with which the individual self-identifies, as well as those linked to the individual by authorities and affiliations mentioned in credible media sources (but not those based on pure speculation without real evidence). If unknown, enter -99. If no organization, enter -88 for N/A.
terrorist_group_name.rest_text: Keshif Label(s): Terrorist Group Affiliation/Inspiration Variable  Recruitment Details

actively_recruited.description: Was the individual actively recruited into an extremist movement?

codes.1: Associate(s) or member(s) of a terrorist or violent extremist group

clique.name: Clique
clique.description: Was the individual part of a clique? A clique is defined as a close-knit, insular, and exclusive group of people containing at least two individuals. A clique can exist within a larger group—e.g. a clique of operatives within al-Qaeda—and separately from an organized group, such as a clique of friends that plans a terrorist attack.

clique_radicalize.name: Clique_Radicalize
clique_radicalize.description: If the individual was part of a clique, did the individual’s radicalization coincide with his/her membership in the clique?
clique_radicalize.rest_text: Keshif Label(s): Radicalize in Clique Variable

codes.-88: No, not a member of a clique
codes.1: Yes, onset of radicalization coincided with clique membership
codes.0: No, radicalization began prior to clique membership

clique_connect.name: Clique_Connect
clique_connect.description: If the individual was part of a clique, did individuals in the clique attempt to connect with an extremist group after radicalizing?
clique_connect.rest_text: Keshif Label(s): Connect with Clique Variable   Radicalization Internet and Media

codes.-88: Not Applicable (individual was not a member of a clique)

internet_radicalization.name: Internet_Radicalization
internet_radicalization.description: What role did the internet play in the individual’s radicalization?

codes.2: Internet was the primary means of radicalization for the individual (e.g. initial exposure to ideology and subsequent radicalization occurred online
codes.1: Internet played a role but was not the primary means of radicalization (e.g. internet resources were used to reaffirm or advance pre-existing radical beliefs)
codes.0: No known role of the internet in individual’s radicalization

media_radicalization.name: Media_Radicalization
media_radicalization.description: What role did media besides the internet (books, movies, television shows, radio) play in the individual’s radicalization?

codes.2: Media was the primary means of radicalization for the individual (e.g. initial exposure to ideology and subsequent radicalization occurred through media)
codes.1: Media played a role but was not the primary means of radicalization (e.g. media resources were used to reaffirm or advance pre-existing radical beliefs)
codes.0: No known role of media in individual’s radicalization

social_media.name: Social_Media
social_media.description: Is there evidence that online social media played a role in the individual’s radicalization and/or mobilization? Online social media is defined as any form of electronic communication through which users create online communities to share information, ideas, personal messages, and other content, such as videos and images. This variable is distinct from Internet_Radicalization in that it emphasizes online user-to-user communication, rather than passively viewing content hosted by an online domain.

codes.2: Yes, it was the primary means of radicalization for the individual (e.g., initial exposure to ideology and subsequent radicalization occurred over online social media)
codes.1: Yes, it played a role but was not the primary means of radicalization or mobilization

social_media_frequency.name: Social_Media_Frequency
social_media_frequency.description: If there is evidence that online social media played a role in the individual’s radicalization and/or mobilization, on average how often did the individual engage in social media-related activity related to radicalization and/or mobilization?

codes.1: Rarely (about once a month or less)

social_media_platform.name: Social_Media_Platform
social_media_platform.description: If there is evidence that online social media played a role in the individual’s radicalization and/or mobilization, which social media platforms did he/she use?

social_media_activities.name: Social_Media_Activities

ideological_sub_category.description: Select the ideological categories that best encapsulate the individual’s radical beliefs. There may be some overlapping ideologies. Select up to three categories.

overseas_family.description: Did the individual have any contact with family overseas? This includes both immediate and extended family.

close_family.description: How emotionally close is the individual to his/her immediate family?

codes.1: Distant (has little regular contact with most family members, rarely attends family events, does not celebrate holidays with family, etc.)

family_religiosity.name: Family_Religiosity

codes.2: Very Religious (Consistently Observant; observes major religious holidays, attends services frequently and regularly, and adheres to strict religious principles)
codes.1: Somewhat Religious (Occasionally Observant; observes major religious holidays and attends religious services on occasion)

For example, an unemployed person who is not actively seeking employment, is not a student, and is not actively engaged in the community, would be considered to have a lot of unstructured time.

friendship_source.name: Friendship_Source
friendship_source.description: From where did the majority of the subject’s friendships come? Select multiple friendship sources if necessary.

codes.1: Previous (non-violent) minor criminal activity (e.g., convicted of a misdemeanor crime)

previous_criminal_activity_type.name: Previous_Criminal_Activity_Type
previous_criminal_activity_type.description: If an individual has a history of non-ideologically motivated crime prior to their radicalization, which of the following activities was he/she involved in?8 If you know they were engaged in criminal behavior prior to their date of exposure, but are unsure of the specific type, enter -99 for unknown. If the individual had never engaged in criminal activity prior to their date of exposure, enter -88. Select up to three choices, putting the corresponding numbers in ascending order. If more than three, select the three most serious offenses (with homicide being the most serious and vandalism being the least serious) and list the remaining offenses in the subsequent text field.
previous_criminal_activity_type.source: PIRUS, adapted from the Uniform Crime Report (FBI), (CSTAB Year 5)

codes.18: Unlawful possession, transportation, or use of a firearm
codes.16: Drug related (e.g., selling/distributing drugs, cultivating drugs, but not simply drug use).
codes.13: Driving Under the Influence (DUI)/Driving While Intoxicated (DWI)
codes.11: Forgery 8 For definitions on these types of criminal activities, refer to Appendix II - Offenses in Uniform Crime Reporting (https://www2.fbi.gov/ucr/cius_04/appendices/appendix_02.html)

previous_criminal_activity_age.name: Previous_Criminal_Activity_Age
previous_criminal_activity_age.description: What age was the individual when they were first involved in non-ideologically motivated criminal activities, if applicable?
